worksheet.stem:
The Maclaurin series expansion for cos x is

 

%media:formula1.mml%

 

Starting with the simplest version, cos x = 1, add terms one at a time to estimate cos(π/3). After each new term is added, compute the true and approximate percent relative errors. Use your calculator to determine the true value. Add terms until the absolute value of the approximate error estimate falls below an error criterion conforming to two significant figures. (Round the value of cos(π/3) to four decimal places and the value of true and approximate error to three decimal places.)

 

Order Value of cos(π/3) True error(%) Approximate error(%)
Zero __a__ __1__  
First __b__ __2__ __6__
Second __c__ __3__ __7__
Third __d__ __4__ __8__

Since the approximate error is below 0.5%, the computation can be terminated.

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

sectionBreak.stem:
The MATLAB function to compute the Maclaurin series expansion for the exponential function is given by

 

function [fx,ea,iter] = IterMeth(x,es,maxit)
% Maclaurin series of exponential function
% [fx,ea,iter] = IterMeth(x,es,maxit)
% input:
% x = value at which series evaluated
% es = stopping criterion (default = 0.0001)
% maxit = maximum iterations (default = 50)
% output:
% fx = estimated value
% ea = approximate relative error (%)
% iter = number of iterations
% defaults:
if nargin < 2|isempty(es),es = 0.0001;end
if nargin < 3|isempty(maxit),maxit = 50;end
% initialization
iter = 1; sol = 1; ea = 100;
% iterative calculation
while (1)
solold = sol;
sol = sol + x ^ iter / factorial(iter);
iter = iter + 1;
if sol~ = 0
ea = abs((sol − solold)/sol)*100;
end
if ea< = es | iter> = maxit,break,end
end
fx = sol;
end

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

doc.stem:
The Maclaurin series expansion for the cosine function is

 

%media:formula31.mml%

 

As the same pattern in the given M-file, develop a well-structured MATLAB function to compute the Maclaurin series expansion for the cosine function.

 

(Please upload your response/solution using the controls below.)
doc.info: question data is all stored in questionProperties...

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

property.name: problemSolution
property.value:
The value of cosine for θ = π/3 is 0.50.

The value of cosine for θ = 7π/3 is 0.50.

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: Are the values of cosine for θ = π/3 and θ = 7π/3 the same?

worksheet.stem:
Use the developed M-file to estimate the values of  the cosine function for θ = π/3 (60°) and θ = 2π + π/3 = 7π/3 (420 °). (Round the final answers to two decimal places.)

 

The value of the cosine for θ = π/3 is __a__.

The value of the cosine for θ = 7π/3 is __b__.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
A MATLAB function can be then written as follows:

 

function [fx,ea,iter] = cosine(x,es,maxit)
% Maclaurin series of cosine
% [fx,ea,iter] = IterMeth(x,es,maxit)
% input:
% x = value at which series evaluated
% es = stopping criterion (default = 0.0001)
% maxit = maximum iterations (default = 50)
% output:
% fx = estimated value
% ea = approximate relative error (%)
% iter = number of iterations

% defaults:
if nargin<2|isempty(es),es=0.0001;end
if nargin<3|isempty(maxit),maxit=50;end
% initialization
iter = 0; sol = 0; ea = 100;
% iterative calculation
while (1)
  solold = sol;
  sol = sol + (-1)^iter * x^(2*iter) / factorial(2*iter);
  iter = iter + 1;
  if sol~=0
    ea=abs((sol - solold)/sol)*100;
  end
  if ea<=es | iter>=maxit,break,end
end
fx = sol;

 

The following script can be used to check if the function yields the correct result:

 

clc, format compact

[ser, ea, i] = cosine(pi/3)

[ser, ea, i] = cosine(7*pi/3)

 

Output

 

ser =
    0.5000
ea =
    8.7408e-05
i  =
    6
ser =
    0.5000
ea =
    6.7791e-05
i =
    16

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

property.name: commonFeedback
property.value: Both cases yield the correct result of cos(π/3) = cos(7π/3) = 0.5. However, more iterations (6 versus 16) are required in the second case to obtain the correct result with the desired approximate absolute error (εa). This is because the second angle is farther away from zero, and hence, more terms in the series are required to attain the desired accuracy.

property.name: problemSolution
property.value: True. The accuracy of the result increases with the number of the iterations.

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: Is the second angle farther away from zero?

trueFalse.stem: The accuracy of the result increases with the number of the iterations.
trueFalse.commonFeedback: Both cases yield the correct result of cos(π/3) = cos(7π/3) = 0.5. However, more iterations (6 versus 16) are required in the second case to obtain the correct result with the desired approximate absolute error (εa). This is because the second angle is farther away from zero, and hence, more terms in the series are required to attain the desired accuracy.

trueInfo.feedback: Both cases yield the correct result of cos(π/3) = cos(7π/3) = 0.5. However, more iterations (6 versus 16) are required in the second case to obtain the correct result with the desired approximate absolute error (εa). This is because the second angle is farther away from zero, and hence, more terms in the series are required to attain the desired accuracy.

falseInfo.feedback: Both cases yield the correct result of cos(π/3) = cos(7π/3) = 0.5. However, more iterations (6 versus 16) are required in the second case to obtain the correct result with the desired approximate absolute error (εa). This is because the second angle is farther away from zero, and hence, more terms in the series are required to attain the desired accuracy.

sectionBreak.stem:
The MATLAB function to compute the Maclaurin series expansion for the exponential function is given by

 

function [fx,ea,iter] = IterMeth(x,es,maxit)
% Maclaurin series of exponential function
% [fx,ea,iter] = IterMeth(x,es,maxit)
% input:
% x = value at which series evaluated
% es = stopping criterion (default = 0.0001)
% maxit = maximum iterations (default = 50)
% output:
% fx = estimated value
% ea = approximate relative error (%)
% iter = number of iterations
% defaults:
if nargin < 2|isempty(es),es = 0.0001;end
if nargin < 3|isempty(maxit),maxit = 50;end
% initialization
iter = 1; sol = 1; ea = 100;
% iterative calculation
while (1)
solold = sol;
sol = sol + x ^ iter / factorial(iter);
iter = iter + 1;
if sol~ = 0
ea = abs((sol − solold)/sol)*100;
end
if ea< = es | iter> = maxit,break,end
end
fx = sol;
end

doc.stem:
The Maclaurin series expansion for the sine function is

 

%media:formula30.mml%

 

As the same pattern in the given M-file, develop a well-structured MATLAB function to compute the Maclaurin series expansion for the sine function.

 

(Please upload your response/solution using the controls below.)
doc.info: question data is all stored in questionProperties...

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

property.name: problemSolution
property.value:
The value of sine for θ = π/3 is 0.866.

The value of sine for θ = 7π/3 is 0.866.

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: are the values of sine for θ = π/3 and θ = 7π/3 the same?

worksheet.stem:
Use the developed M-file to estimate the values of the sine function for θ = π/3 (60°) and θ = 2π + π/3 = 7π/3 (420°). (Round the final answers to three decimal places.)

 

The value of the sine for θ = π/3 is __a__.

The value of the sine for θ = 7π/3 is __b__.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
It is useful to first express the series as a summation.

 

%media:formula32.mml%

 

A MATLAB function can be then written as follows:

 

function [fx,ea,iter] = sine(x,es,maxit)
% Maclaurin series of cosine
% [fx,ea,iter] = IterMeth(x,es,maxit)
% input:
% x = value at which series evaluated
% es = stopping criterion (default = 0.0001)
% maxit = maximum iterations (default = 50)
% output:
% fx = estimated value
% ea = approximate relative error (%)
% iter = number of iterations

% defaults:
if nargin<2||isempty(es),es=0.0001;end
if nargin<3||isempty(maxit),maxit=50;end
% initialization
iter = 0; sol = 0; ea = 100;
% iterative calculation
while (1)
  solold = sol;
  sol = sol + (-1)^iter * x^(2*iter+1) / factorial(2*iter+1);
  iter = iter + 1;
  if sol~=0
    ea=abs((sol - solold)/sol)*100;
  end
  if ea<=es || iter>=maxit,break,end
end
fx = sol;

 

The following script can be used to check that the function yields the correct result:

 

clc, format compact
[ser, ea, i] = sine(pi/3)
[ser, ea, i] = sine(7*pi/3)

 

Output

 

ser =
     0.8660
ea =
     4.8043e-06
i =
     6
ser =
     0.8660
ea =
     9.2549e-06
i =
     16

This is because the second angle is farther away from zero and hence more terms in the series are required.

%media:formula33.mml%

property.value:
The true value is 0.48234.

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: What is the Maclaurin series expansion for the arctan x?

worksheet.stem:
Starting with the simplest version, arctan x = x, add terms one at a time to estimate arctan(π/6). After each new term is added, compute the true and approximate percent relative errors. Determine the true value. Add terms until the absolute value of the approximate error estimate falls below an error criterion conforming to two significant figures.Stopping criterion εs = 0.5%. (Round the final answers to five decimal places, and round the true and absolute percent relative error to two decimal places.)

 

True value is __v__ . (Round the final answer to six decimal places.)

 

The solutions are as follows:

 

  The value of arctan (π/6) True error(%) Approximate  error(%)
Zero order __a__ __f__  
First order __b__ __g__% __i__%
Second order __c__ 0.26% __j__%
Third order __d__ __h__% 0.32%
worksheet.commonFeedback:
Use the stopping criterion εs = 0.5 × 102 – 2% = 0.5%

The true value is given by

arctan(π/6) = 0.48234

Since the approximate error is below 0.5%, the computation can be terminated.
